prompt: Declare variables with primitive data types and print their values
answer:
### Declaring Variables with Primitive Data Types and Printing their Values

Below is an example code in Python that declares variables with primitive data types and prints their values.

```python
# Declare variables with primitive data types
boolean_value = True
integer_value = 10
float_value = 3.14
string_value = "Hello, World!"
character_value = 'A'

# Print the values of the variables
print("Boolean Value:", boolean_value)
print("Integer Value:", integer_value)
print("Float Value:", float_value)
print("String Value:", string_value)
print("Character Value:", character_value)

# Print the data types of the variables
print("\nData Types:")
print("Boolean Value:", type(boolean_value))
print("Integer Value:", type(integer_value))
print("Float Value:", type(float_value))
print("String Value:", type(string_value))
print("Character Value:", type(character_value))
```

### Output

When you run the above code, it will print the values and data types of the variables.

```
Boolean Value: True
Integer Value: 10
Float Value: 3.14
String Value: Hello, World!
Character Value: A

Data Types:
Boolean Value: <class 'bool'>
Integer Value: <class 'int'>
Float Value: <class 'float'>
String Value: <class 'str'>
Character Value: <class 'str'>
```

Note: In Python, there is no explicit character data type. A single character is represented as a string of length 1.
